snippet: Iranians went to the polls in a parliamentary vote on Friday likely to reflect a struggle for influence and position among the country’s top leaders.
abstract: Iran's government declares an enormous turnout for parliamentary elections, calling it a sign of support for Iranian theocracy; nation's opposition movement, whose leaders have been jailed or placed under house arrest, called for a boycott of the election, which is the first national vote since disputed presidential election in 2009.

byline.contributor: J. David Goodman contributed reporting from New York, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: Iranians went to the polls in a parliamentary vote on Friday likely to reflect a struggle for influence and position among the country’s top leaders.

headline.seo: Iran’s Government Declares Huge Election Turnout
headline.main: Iran’s Government Declares Huge Turnout in First National Vote Since ’09 Protests
headline.print_headline: Iran’s Government Declares Huge Turnout in First National Vote Since ’09 Protests
